lesson.name: Lesson 9.9: Using Quadratic Expressions in Vertex Form to Solve Problems

page.title: 9.9.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn how to use the vertex form of a quadratic to determine the maximum or minimum value of a function and to solve problems.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Find the maximum or minimum of a function by writing the quadratic expression that defines it in vertex form.
  • Explain why the vertex is a maximum or minimum when given a quadratic function in vertex form.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 9.9.1: Maximum and Minimum Value of a Function
  • 9.9.2: Does the Vertex Represent the Minimum or Maximum Value?
    • 9.9.2: Self Check
    • 9.9.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.9.3: Comparing Maximums between Quadratics
    • 9.9.3: Self Check
    • 9.9.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.9.4: Maximum, Minimum, and Analyzing the Vertex

After that, you'll practice and review.

  • 9.9.5: Practice
  • 9.9.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 9.9.1: Maximum and Minimum Value of a Function
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Examine the graph that represents the function, \(f\), defined by \(f(x)=(x−4)^2+1\).

Use this graph to answer questions 1 and 2.

  1. \(f(1)\) can be expressed in words as "the value of \(f\) when \(x\) is 1." Find or compute:
  1. the value of \(f\) when \(x\) is 1

Enter the value of \(f\).

Correct! 10

The correct answer is 10.

  1. \( f(3)\)

Enter the value of \(f(3)\).

Correct! 2

The correct answer is 2.

  1. \(f(10)\)

Enter the value of \(f(10)\).

Correct! 37

The correct answer is 37.

  1. Can you find an \(x\)-value that would make \(f(x)\):
  1. Less than 1?

Correct! No, from the graph, it seems that 1 is the least value of \(f\), and that occurs when \(x=4\). All other \(x\)-values produce outputs that are greater than 1.

Incorrect. The correct answer is no. From the graph, it seems that 1 is the least value of \(f\), and that occurs when \(x=4\). All other \(x\)-values produce outputs that are greater than 1.

  1. Greater than 10,000?

Correct! Yes, there are lots of \(x\)-values that produce an output greater than 10,000. For example, both -100 and 110 would make \(f(x)\) greater than 10,000.

Incorrect. The correct answer is yes. There are lots of \(x\)-values that produce an output greater than 10,000. For example, both -100 and 110 would make \(f(x)\) greater than 10,000.

Examine the graph that represents the function, \(g\), defined by \(g(x)=-(x−12)^2+7\).

Use this graph to answer questions 3 and 4.

  1. \(g(9)\) can be expressed in words as "the value of \(g\) when \(x\) is 9." Find or compute:
  1. the value of \(g\) when \(x\) is 9

Enter the value of \(g\).

Correct! -2

The correct answer is -2.

  1. \(g(13)\)

Enter the value of \(g(13)\).

Correct! 6

The correct answer is 6.

  1. \(g(2)\)

Enter the value of \(g(2)\).

Correct! -93

The correct answer is -93.

  1. Can you find an \(x\)-value that would make \(g(x)\):
  1. Greater than 7?

Correct! No, it seems that 7 is the greatest value of \(g\), and that occurs when \(x=12\). All other \(x\)-values produce outputs that are less than 7.

Incorrect. The correct answer is no. From the graph, it seems that 7 is the greatest value of \(g\), and that occurs when \(x=12\). All other \(x\)-values produce outputs that are less than 7.

  1. Less than -10,000?

Correct! Yes, there are lots of \(x\)-values that produce an output less than -10,000. For example, both -200 and 200 would make \(g(x)\) greater than -10,000.

Incorrect. The correct answer is yes. There are lots of \(x\)-values that produce an output less than -10,000. For example, both -200 and 200 would make \(g(x)\) greater than -10,000.

page.title: 9.9.2: Does the Vertex Represent the Minimum or Maximum Value?
page.contents:
Activity

  1. The graph that represents \(p(x)=(x−8)^2+1\) has its vertex (of a graph) at \((8,1)\). Here is one way to show, without graphing, that \((8,1)\) corresponds to the minimum value of \(p\).
  • When \(x=8\), the value of \((x−8)^2\) is 0 because \((8−8)^2=0^2=0\).
  • Squaring any number always results in a positive number, so when \(x\) is any value other than 8, \((x−8)\) will be a number other than 0, and when squared, \((x−8)^2\) will be positive.
  • Any positive number is greater than 0, so when \(x \neq 8\), the value of \((x−8)^2\) will be greater than when \(x=8\). In other words, \(p\) has the least value when \(x=8\).

Use similar reasoning to explain why the point \((4,1)\) corresponds to the maximum value of \(q\), defined by \(q(x)=-2(x−4)^2+1\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

  • When \(x=4\), the value of \((x−4)^2\) is 0 because \(-2(4−4)^2=-2(0^2)=0\).
  • Squaring any number always results in a positive number, so when \(x\) is any value other than 4 (either greater or less), \((x−4)\) will be a number other than 0. When squared, \((x−4)^2\) will be positive, but then it gets multiplied to a negative number, so the product will be negative.
  • Any negative number is less than 0, so when \(x \neq 4\), the value of \(-2(x−4)^2\) will be less than when \(x=4\). In other words, \(q\) has the greatest value when \(x=4\).

The greatest value of a function is the maximum value. The lowest value of a function is the minimum value. Since infinity cannot be reached or touched, it is not considered a maximum or minimum.

In quadratic functions, the maximum or minimum value occurs at the vertex of the parabola.

  1. Here are some quadratic functions and the coordinates of the vertex of the graph of each. Determine if the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function.

Equation

Coordinates of the vertex

a.

\(f(x)=-(x−4)^2+6\)

\((4,6)\)

b.

\(g(x)=(x+7)^2−3\)

\((-7,-3)\)

c.

\(h(x)=4(x+5)^2+7\)

\((-5,7)\)

d.

\(k(x)=x^2−6x−3\)

\((3,-12)\)

e.

\(m(x)=-x^2+8x\)

\((4,16)\)

  1. Determine if the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function \(f(x)=-(x−4)^2+6\).

Correct! Maximum

Incorrect. The correct answer is maximum. The leading coefficient is negative, so the parabola opens down.

  1. Determine if the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function \(g(x)=(x+7)^2−3\).

Correct! Minimum

Incorrect. The correct answer is minimum. The leading coefficient is positive, so the parabola opens up.

  1. Determine if the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function \(h(x)=4(x+5)^2+7\).

Correct! Minimum

Incorrect. The correct answer is minimum. The leading coefficient is positive, so the parabola opens up.

  1. Determine if the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function \(k(x)=x^2−6x−3\).

Correct! Minimum

Incorrect. The correct answer is minimum. The leading coefficient is positive, so the parabola opens up.

  1. Determine if the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function \(m(x)=-x^2+8x\).

Correct! Maximum

Incorrect. The correct answer is maximum. The leading coefficient is negative, so the parabola opens down.


Extending Your Thinking

Here is a portion of the graph of function \(q\), defined by \(q(x)=-x^2+14x−40\).

\(ABCD\) is a rectangle. Points \(A\) and \(B\) coincide with the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph, and segment \(CD\) just touches the vertex of the graph.

Find the area of \(ABCD\). Show your reasoning.

Enter the area of \(ABCD\) and your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

54 square units.

For example:

  • The expression can be rewritten in factored form as \((-x+10)(x−4)\), so the \(x\)-intercepts are \((4,0)\) and \((10,0)\), which means the length of \(AB\) is 6 units. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is halfway between 4 and 10, which is 7. Substituting 7 for \(x\) in \((- x + 10)(x − 4)\) gives \(3 \cdot 3\) or 9, so the height of the rectangle is 9. The area is \(6 \cdot 9\) or 54 square units.
  • The equation \(q(x)=-x^2+14x−40\) can be written in vertex form as \(q(x)=-1(x−7)^2+9\), so its vertex is at \((7,9)\) and the height of the rectangle is 9 units. Completing the square for \(-x^2+14x−40=0\) gives the solutions \(x=4\) and \(x=10\), which correspond to the \(x\)-intercepts at points \(A\) and \(B\). This means the width of the rectangle is \(10−4\) or 6 units.

page.title: 9.9.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is the correct vertex for \(h(x)=-3(x-2)^2+5\)? Describe the vertex as a maximum or minimum.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The \(x\)-value is the opposite sign of what is there, and the \(y\)-value remains the same sign. The answer is \((2, 5)\), maximum.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Since the leading coefficient is negative, the parabola opens down and the vertex is a maximum value. The answer is \((2, 5)\), maximum.
That's correct! Check yourself: Since the leading coefficient is negative, the parabola opens down and the vertex is a maximum value.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The \(x\)-value is the opposite sign of what is there, and the \(y\)-value remains the same sign. The answer is \((2, 5)\), maximum.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 9.9.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Identify a Maximum or Minimum

Recall that the maximum is the highest point of the graph and the minimum is the lowest point of the graph. A quadratic function shape is called a parabola, and a parabola will only have a maximum or a minimum.

Example 1

Graph \(f(x)=(x-2)^2-1\).

In the vertex form (of a quadratic expression), \(f(x)=a(x-h)^2+k\), tthe vertex (of a graph) is located at \((h, k)\).

For the function graphed, the vertex is at \((2, -1)\).

Since the leading coefficient, \(a\), is positive, the parabola opens up. This means the vertex is a minimum.

Example 2

Graph \(f(x)=-(x+1)^2+3\).

The vertex is located at \((-1, 3)\).

Since the leading coefficient is negative, the parabola opens down and the vertex is a maximum.

Try It: Identify a Maximum or Minimum

For the function \(f(x)=(x+4)^2-2\), identify the vertex and tell if it is a maximum or minimum.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to identify if a vertex is a maximum or minimum:

Step 1
Identify the vertex \((h, k)\).
\((-4, 2)\)

Step 2
Identify if the parabola opens up or down.
Since the leading coefficient is positive, the parabola opens up.

Step 3
Identify if the vertex is a maximum or minimum.
Since the parabola opens up, the vertex is a minimum.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.9.3: Comparing Maximums between Quadratics
page.contents:
Activity

A function \(A\), defined by \(p(600−75p)\), describes the revenue collected from the sales of tickets for Performance A, a musical.

The graph represents a function \(B\) that models the revenue collected from the sales of tickets for Performance B, a Shakespearean comedy.

In both functions, \(p\) represents the price of one ticket, and both revenues and prices are measured in dollars.

Without creating a graph of \(A\), determine which performance gives the greater maximum revenue when tickets are \(p\) dollars each. Explain or show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Performance A.

  • The maximum revenue for Performance B is $900 based on the vertex (of a graph) of its graph. For Performance A, the expression \(p(600−75p)\) is in factored form, which tells us that the horizontal intercepts are \((0,0)\) and \((8,0)\). The horizontal coordinate of the vertex is halfway between 0 and 8, which is 4. Substituting 4 for \(p\) in \(p(600−75p)\) gives 1200, so the vertex is at \((4,1200)\). 1200 is greater than 900.
  • The maximum revenue for Performance B is $900 based on the vertex of its graph. The expression \(p(600−75p)\) can be rewritten in vertex form (of a quadratic expression): \(-75(p−4)^2+1200\), which tells us that the vertex of a graph of the function is at \((4,1200)\) and that the maximum revenue is $1200.

Video: Comparing Maximums between Quadratics

Watch the following video to learn more about comparing maximums between quadratics.

page.title: 9.9.3: Self Check
page.contents: A function, defined by \(p(600−60p)\), describes the revenue collected from the sales of tickets for a concert where \(p\) is the price of one ticket. Find the maximum revenue, in dollars.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex. The \(y\)-value is needed for the maximum. The correct answer is 1500.
That's correct! Check yourself: \(x=5\) is the value halfway between the horizontal intercepts and is the \(x\)-value of the vertex. Substitute into \(p(600−60p)\) to find the maximum revenue.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the other horizontal intercept, besides 0. The correct answer is 1500.

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is not the maximum value. First, find the horizontal intercepts, and then find the halfway point and location of the vertex. The correct answer is 1500.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 9.9.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Finding Maximum Revenue

The revenue brought in by a newspaper is modeled by \(R=p(-2500p+159,000)\). Find the maximum revenue where \(R\) is revenue and \(p\) is price per newspaper subscription.

  1. Find the horizontal intercepts (where \(p=0\)).

This occurs at \(p=0\) or \((0, 0)\).

\(-2500p+159,000=0\)

\(p=63.6\)

The vertex (of a graph) will occur halfway between \(p=0\) and \(p=63.6\).

This occurs when \(p=31.8\).

  1. Write in standard form and substitute \(p=31.8\).

\(R=-2500p^2+159,000p\)

\(R=-2500(31.8)^2+159,000(31.8)\)

The maximum revenue is at $2,528,100 with a $31.80 subscription.

Try It: Finding Maximum Revenue

Suppose that the price per unit in dollars of a cell phone production is modeled by \(p=$45-0.0125x\), where \(x\) is in thousands of phones produced, and the revenue represented by thousands of dollars is \(R=x \cdot p\). Find the production level that will maximize revenue and the maximum revenue.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the maximum revenue:

Step 1
Find the horizontal intercepts.
\(x=0\) and
\(p=45-0.0125x\)
\(x=3600\)

Step 2
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex halfway through the horizontal intercepts.
This is the number of phones produced for the maximum revenue.
\(x=1800\)

Step 3
Find the equation for \(R\) and substitute \(x=1800\) to find the maximum revenue.
\(R=-0.0125x^2+45x\)
\(R=-0.0125(1800)^2+45(1800))\)
\(R=$40,500\)

answer.answer_text: ’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.9.4: Maximum, Minimum, and Analyzing the Vertex
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

  1. Without graphing, find the vertex (of a graph) of the graph of a quadratic function defined by \(f(x)=-x^2−14x−60\). Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The vertex is at \((-7,-11)\).

\(f(x)=-(x^2+14x+60)\)

\(f(x)=-(x^2+14x+49+11)\)

\(f(x)=-((x+7)^2+11)\)

\(f(x)=-(x+7)^2−11\)


  1. Does the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex correspond to a maximum or a minimum value of the function? Explain how you know.

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

A maximum value. The squared term has a coefficient of -1. The squared term will be 0 when \(x\) is -7. For all other values of \(x\), the squared term will be subtracted from -11, resulting in outputs that are less than -11.

Note: If the vertex isn't asked for and the "value of the maximum or minimum" is asked for, the maximum or minimum value occurs at the \(y\)-value of the vertex because that is the value of the coordinate that represents the vertical height of the point.

page.title: 9.9.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Find the maximum or minimum of a function by writing the quadratic expression that defines it in vertex form.
  • Explain why the vertex is a maximum or minimum when given a quadratic function in vertex form.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 9.9.1: Maximum and Minimum Value of a Function
    • In this activity, you reviewed the meaning of maximum or minimum value of a function. Then you practiced interpreting the language related to maximum and minimum values of functions.
  • 9.9.2: Does the Vertex Represent the Minimum or Maximum Value?
    • In this activity, you used the vertex form to find out if a vertex represents the minimum or the maximum value of each function.
    • 9.9.2: Self Check
    • 9.9.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.9.3: Comparing Maximums between Quadratics
    • In this activity, you were given two functions in different forms. One was graphed, and the other was in factored form. You used these two pieces of information, without creating a graph of the function in factored form, to determine the maximum value of each one.
    • 9.9.3: Self Check
    • 9.9.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.9.4: Maximum, Minimum, and Analyzing the Vertex
    • In this activity, you found the vertex of the graph of a quadratic function and then determined if the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex corresponded to a maximum or a minimum value of the function.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 9.9.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 9.9.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Here is a graph of a quadratic function \(f(x)\). What is the minimum value of \(f(x)\)?

Enter the minimum value of \(f(x)\).

Correct! The minimum value of \(f(x)\) is 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.9.2 and 9.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. The minimum value of \(f(x)\) is 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph that represents \(f(x)=(x+1)^2−4\) has its vertex at \((-1,-4)\).

Explain how we can tell from the expression \((x+1)^2−4\) that -4 is the minimum value of \(f\) rather than the maximum value.

Correct! The coefficient of the quadratic term is positive; therefore, the vertex will be a minimum value.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.9.2 and 9.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The coefficient of the quadratic term is positive; therefore, the vertex will be a minimum value. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(g(x)=(x−5)^2+6\) defines a quadratic function. Find the vertex of the graph of the function. Then, state whether the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is 5.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 5. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is 5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is 6.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 6. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is 6. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Does the vertex correspond to the maximum or the minimum value of the function?

Correct! Minimum

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.9.2–9.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: minimum. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(h(x)=(x+5)^2−1\) defines a quadratic function. Find the vertex of the graph of the function. Then, state whether the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -5.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -5. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -1. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Does the vertex correspond to the maximum or the minimum value of the function?

Correct! Minimum

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.9.2–9.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: minimum. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(f(x)=-2(x+3)^2−10\) defines a quadratic function. Find the vertex of the graph of the function. Then, state whether the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -3.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -3. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -10.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -10. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -10. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Does the vertex correspond to the maximum or the minimum value of the function?

Correct! Maximum

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.9.2–9.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: maximum. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(p(x)=3(x−7)^2+11\) defines a quadratic function. Find the vertex of the graph of the function. Then, state whether the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is 7.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 7. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is 7. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is 11.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 11. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is 11. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Does the vertex correspond to the maximum or the minimum value of the function?

Correct! Minimum

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.9.2–9.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: minimum. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(g(x)=-(x−2)^2−2\) defines a quadratic function. Find the vertex of the graph of the function. Then, state whether the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is 2.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 2. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is 2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -2.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -2. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Does the vertex correspond to the maximum or the minimum value of the function?

Correct! Maximum

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.9.2–9.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: maximum. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(h(x)=(x+1)^2\) defines a quadratic function. Find the vertex of the graph of the function. Then, state whether the vertex corresponds to the maximum or the minimum value of the function.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -1. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Does the vertex correspond to the maximum or the minimum value of the function?

Correct! Minimum

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.9.2–9.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: minimum. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A backyard farmer wants to enclose a rectangular space for a new garden within her fenced backyard. She has purchased 80 feet of wire fencing to enclose three sides, and she will use a section of the backyard fence as the fourth side. The function is graphed below. What is the maximum area, in square feet, that can be fenced in?

Enter the maximum area.

Correct! The maximum area is 800 square feet.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.9.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 800. The maximum area is 800 square feet. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
